subject: Home & DIY
title: Stainless Steel's Invisible Shield
description: A 60-second lesson on Stainless Steel's Invisible Shield.

hook.text: Stainless steel resists staining because chromium forms a self-healing oxide layer just 5 nanometers thick.

buildup.text: Add 10.5% chromium to steel and it becomes 'stainless.' Chromium reacts with oxygen to form chromium oxide instantly.

discovery.text: Scratch stainless steel and the oxide reforms in milliseconds. The surface literally heals itself from damage, nonstop.

twist.text: Stainless can still rustâ€”chlorine from bleach or salt attacks the chromium layer, causing pitting corrosion.

climax.text: Sinks, appliances, and cutlery use grade 304. Coastal settings need 316 with added molybdenum for salt resistance.

punchline.text: A 5-nanometer shield makes steel last centuries.

quiz.question: How does stainless steel protect itself from corrosion?
options: Chromium creates a self-healing oxide layer that reforms when scratched
A special coating is applied during manufacturing that never wears off
The steel is so dense that oxygen cannot penetrate its surface
